entry.content:
Moment Generating Function

Definition

For a random variable $X$, if $E[e^{tx}]$ exists $ orall t \in(-h, h)$ for some $h>0$, moment generating function $M(t)=E[e^{tx}]$

Properties

$X$ is a random variable with MGF $M_x(t)$ that exists $ orall t\in (-h,h)$ where $h>0$,

  • $Y=aX+b$ where $a,b\in \R$ and $a e 0$. Then, $M_y(t)=e^{bt}M_x(at) orall t\in (- rac{h}{\vert a\vert}, rac{h}{\vert a\vert})$
  • $M(0)=1$ ,and
  • $M^{(k)}(0)=E[x^k]$ where $M^{(k)}(t)= rac{d^k}{dt^k}M(t)$ for $k=1,2,…$
  • Uniqueness: $M_x(t)=M_y(t) orall t\in(-h, h)\iff X$ and $Y$ have the same distribution

    Multivariate Random Function

    Definition

    Suppose $X$ and $Y$ are $r.v$ defined on the sample space $S$,
  • Joint $CDF$ of $X$ and $Y$:
    $F(x,y)=P(\underbrace{X\le x,Y\le y}_{intersection\space of\space 2\space events}) orall(x,y)\in\R^2$
  • Marginal $CDF$ of $X$ and $Y$: (holds for both discrete and continuous $r.v.$)
    $F_1(x)/F_x(x)= \lim\limits_{y arr \infty}F(x,y)=P(X\le x), orall x\in \R$
    $F_2(y)/F_y(y)= \lim\limits_{x arr \infty}F(x,y)=P(Y\le y), orall y\in \R$
  • Marginal $PDF$ of $X$ and $Y$:
    • For discrete $r.v.$,
      • $f_x(x)=P(X=x)=\displaystyle\sum_{all\space y}f(x,y) orall x\in\R$
      • $f_y(y)=P(Y=y)=\displaystyle\sum_{all\space x}f(x,y) orall y\in\R$
    • For continuous $r.v.$,
      • $f_x(x)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}f(x,y)dy orall x\in\R$
      • $f_y(y)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}f(x,y)dx orall y\in\R$

        Independence

        Recall: Independent events are $P(A\cap B)=P(A)P(B)$
        Theorem
        $X$ ans $Y$ are $r.v.$
  1. If joint CDF $F(x,y)$, marginal CDFs $F_1(x)$ and $F_2(y)$, then $X$ and $Y$ are independent $\iff F(x,y)=F_1(x)F_2(y) orall(x,y)\in\R^2$
  2. If joint $pdf/pmf$ $f(x,y)$ and marginal $pdfs/pmfs$ $f_1(x)$ and $f_2(y)$ and $A_1={s:f_1(x)>0}$, $A_2={y:f_2(y)>0}$, $X$ and $Y$ are independent $\iff f(x,y)=f_1(x)f_2(y) orall(x,y)\in(A_1 imes A_2)$
  3. (factorization theorem of independence) If joint $pdf/pmf$ $f(x,y)$ and $A_1={s:f_1(x)>0}$, $A_2={y:f_2(y)>0}$, $X$ and $Y$ are independent $\iff\exist g(y)\ge 0$ such that $f(x,y)=g(x)h(y) orall(x,y)\in(A_1 imes A_2)$
  4. If support $A$ is not rectangular, then $X$ and $Y$ must be dependent $i.e.$
    $\exist(x,y)s.t.x\in A_1,y\in A_2, but(x,y) otin A \space i.e.$
    $f_1(x)>0, f_2(y)>0,f(x,y)=0$
  5. if $X$ and $Y$ are independent random variables, then if $g,h$ are functions, then $g(x)$ and $h(y)$ are independent. (the reverse is false)

    Joint Expectations

    Definition

  • Suppose $X$ and $Y$ are bivariate discrete random variables and $h(x,y)$ is a real-valued function. Then, if $\displaystyle\sum_{(x,y)\in A}\vert h(x,y)\vert f(x,y)<\infty$, then $E[h(x,y)]=\displaystyle\sum_{(x,y)\in A}h(x,y)f(x,y)$. Otherwise, $E[h(x,y)]$ DNE.
  • Suppose $X$ and $Y$ are bivariate continuous random variables and $h(x,y)$ is a real-valued function. Then, if $\int_{-\infty}^\infty\int_{-\infty}^\infty\vert h(x,y)\vert f(x,y)dxdy<\infty,E[h(x,y)]=\int_{-\infty}^\infty\int_{-\infty}^\infty h(x,y) f(x,y)dxdy$. Otherwise, $E[h(x,y]$ DNE.

    Properties

  1. Linearity
  2. If $X$ and $Y$ are independent, then $ orall function\space g,h,E[g(X)h(Y)]=E[g(X)]E[h(Y)]$

    Covariance

    $Cov(X,Y)=E[(x-\mu_x)(y-\mu_y)],where\space\mu_x=E[X], \mu_y=E[Y]$
    $Cov(X,Y)=0$, we say $X$ and $Y$ are uncorrelated

    Properties

  3. $Cov(X,Y)=E[XY]-E[X]E[Y]$
  4. $X$ and $Y$ are independent $\implies Cov(X,Y)=0$
  5. $Cov(X,X)=Var(X)$
  6. $Var(aX+bY)=a^2Var(X)+b^2Var(Y)+2abCov(X,Y)$
  7. $Var[\sum_{i=1}^na_iX_i]=\sum_{i=1}^na_i^2Var(X_i)+\sum_{i e j}a_ia_jCov(X_i,X_j)$
  8. $Cov(X+Y,Z)=Cov(X,Y)+Cov(Y,Z)$

    Correlation Coefficient

    $$
    ho(x,y)= rac{Cov(X,Y)}{\sqrt{Var(X)}\sqrt{Var(Y)}}
    $$
    $-1< ho<1$ measures the strength of linear relationship between $X$ and $Y$

    Conditional Distribution

    $$
    P(A\mid B)= rac{P(A\cap B)}{P(B)} \space ,given \space P(B)>0
    $$
    Suppose $X$ and $Y$ are bivariate random variables with joint pmf $f(x,y)$, then
  9. conditional pmf/pdf of $X$ given $Y=y$ is
    $$
    f_1(x\mid y)= rac{f(x,y)}{f_2(y)}\space,given\space f_2(y)>0
    $$
  10. conditional pmf/pdf of $Y$ given $X=x$ is
    $$
    f_2(y\mid x)= rac{f(x,y)}{f_1(x)}\space,given\space f_1(x)>0
    $$

    Properties

    $X$ and $Y$ are random variables with marginal pdf/pmf $f_1(x)$ and $f_2(y)$ and marginal support $A_1$ and $A_2$
  11. $X$ and $Y$ are independent $\iff f_1(x\mid y)=f_1(x) orall x\in A_1 \lor f_2(y\mid x)=f_2(y) orall y\in A_2$
  12. Product Rule: $f(x,y)=f_1(x\mid y)f_2(y)=f_2(y\mid x)f_1(x)$

    Conditional Expectations

    Function $g$, the conditional expectation of $g(Y)$ given $X=x$ is:
    $$
    E[g(Y)\mid X=x] = egin{cases}
    \displaystyle\sum_{all\space y}g(y)f_x(y\mid x) & ext{if Y is discrete r.v.} \
    \int_{-\infty}^\infty g(y)f_2(y\mid x)dy & ext{if Y is continuous r.v.}
    \end{cases}, unless \sum_{all\space y}g(y)f_x(y\mid x)/\int_{-\infty}^\infty g(y)f_2(y\mid x)dy ext{ does not converge,\ in which case} E[g(Y)\mid X=x] DNE
    $$
  • $g(Y)=Y$, $E[Y\mid X=x]$ is called the conditional mean
  • $g(y)=(y-E[Y\mid X=x])^2\implies egin{aligned}Var[Y\mid X=x] &= E ig[(Y-E[Y\mid X=x])^2\mid X=x ig]\&=E[Y^2\mid X=x]- ig(E[y\mid X=x] ig)^2\end{aligned}$ is called conditional variance

    Properties

  1. Independence: If $X$ and $Y$ are independent, $ orall g(\sdot) and\space h(\sdot),E[g(x)\mid Y=y] = E[g(x)]$ and $E[h(y)\mid X=x] = E[h(y)]$
  2. Substitution Rule: $E[h(X,Y)\mid X=x]=E[h(x,Y)\mid X=x]$
  3. Double Expectation: $E[G(Y)]=E ig[E[g(Y)\mid X] ig]$
  4. $Var[Y]=E[\underbrace{Var(Y\mid X)}_{function\space h(x)=Var[Y\mid X = x]\space applied \space to \space r.v.\space X}]+Var[E[Y\vert X]]$
    1. $E[Var(Y\vert X)]$ :
      • find $Var(Y\vert X)$
        • figure out the expression for $h(x)=Var(Y\vert X)$
        • substitute $X$ for big $x$ in that expression
      • calculate $E[h(X)]$
    2. $Var[E[Y\vert X]]$:
      • find $E[Y\vert X]$
      • calculate $Var[\overbrace{E[Y\vert X]}^ ext{~{h}(x)}]$

        Joint Moment Generating Function(MGF)

        $X$ and $Y$ are random variables. If $E[e^{t_1x+t_2y}]$ exists $ orall t_1\in(-h_1,h_1)$ and $t_2\in(-h_2,h_2)$ for $h_1,h_2>0$
        Then, $M(t_1,t_2)=E[e^{t_1x+t_2y}] orall t_1,t_2$such that $E[\sdot]$ exists is called the joint MGF

        Marginal joint MGF

        Given $M(t_1,t_2)$
  • $M_x(t_1)=M(t_1,0)=E[e^{t_1x+0y}]=E[e^{t_1x}]$
  • $M_y(t_2)=M(0,t_2)=E[e^{0x+t_2y}]=E[e^{t_2y}]$

    Properties

    $X$ and $Y$ are random variables with joint MGF $M(t_1,t_2)$. Then,
    $X$ and $Y$ are independent $\iff M(t_1,t_2)=M_x(t_1)M_y(t_2)$

    Multinomial Distribution

$$
(X_1,X_2,…,X_k)\sim Multinomial(n;p_1,p_2,…,p_k) ext{ is discrete random variable with joint pmf} \ f(x_1,x_2,…,x_k)= egin{cases} rac{n!}{x_1!x_2!…x_k!}p_1^{x_1}p_2^{x_2}…p_k^{x_k} &x_i=0,1,…,n, i=1,2,…,k,\sum_{i=1}^kx_1=n\0 &o.w. \end{cases} \ for\space 0<p_i<1, \sum_{i=1}^kp_i=1
$$
Concrete example: k boxes randomly pick one of the k boxes, probability of picking the $i^{th}$ box being $p_i$. Repeat picking n times independently. $X_i$ is number of times box $i$ was picked, $i=1,2,…,k$

Properties

$(X_1,X_2,…,X_k)\sim Multinomial(n;p_1,p_2,…,p_k)$

  1. Joint MGF $M(t_1,t_2,…,t_k)=E[e^{t_1x_1+t_2x_2+…+t_kx_k}]=(p_1e^{t_1}+…+p_ke^{t_k})^n orall (t_1,t_2,…,t_k)\in \R^k$
  2. $X_i\sim Binomial(n,p_i)for\space i=1,2,…,k$
  3. $T=X_i+X_j(i e j)\implies T\sim Binomial(n,p_i+p_j)$
  4. $$E[X_i]=np_i\Var[X_i]=np_i(1-p_i)\Cov(X_i,X_j)=-np_ip_j(i e j)$$
  5. $X_i\mid X_j=x_j\sim Bin(n-x_j, rac{p_i}{1-p_j}),i e j$
  6. $X_i\mid X_i+X_j=t\sim Bin(t, rac{p_i}{p_i+p_j}),i e j$

    Bivariate Normal Distribution

    $$
    \overrightarrow{x}= egin{pmatrix}x_1\x_2\end{pmatrix}\sim BVN(\overrightarrow{\mu},\Sigma)\ where\space X_1\space and\space X_2 ext{ are continutous random variables with joint pdf } (x_1,x_2)= rac{1}{2\pi |\Sigma|^{1/2}}exp{ rac{-(x-\mu)\Sigma^{-1}(x-\mu)^T}{2}},\ where\ x= egin{pmatrix}x_1\x_2\end{pmatrix},\mu= egin{pmatrix}\mu_1\ \mu_2\end{pmatrix},\Sigma= egin{pmatrix}\sigma_1^2 & ho\sigma_1\sigma_2\ ho\sigma_1\sigma_2 & \sigma_2^2\end{pmatrix} is\ positive\ definite
    $$

    Properties

  7. $X_1,X_2$ has joint MGF$$M(t_1,t_2)=E[e^{t_1x_1+t_2x_2}]=exp{t^T\mu+ rac{1}{2}t^T\Sigma t} orall t= egin{pmatrix}t_1 _2\end{pmatrix}\in\R^2$$
  8. $M_{x_1}(t)=M(t,0)=exp{t_1\mu_1+ rac{1}{2}t_1^2\sigma_1^2} o X_1\sim N(\mu,\sigma_1^2)\M_{x_2}(t)=M(0,t)=exp{t_2\mu_2+ rac{1}{2}t_2^2\sigma_2^2} o X_2\sim N(\mu,\sigma_2^2)$
  9. $Cov(X_1,X_2)= ho\sigma_1\sigma_2$
  10. $ ho=0\iff X_1\ and\ X_2$ are independent and correlated
  11. $c= egin{pmatrix}c_1\c_2\end{pmatrix} e 0,\ c^TX=c_1x_1+c_2x_2\sim N(\mu^Tc,c^T\Sigma c)$
  12. Nonsingular matrix $A\in\R^{2 imes 2},b\in\R^2,\ then\ AX+b\sim BVN(A\mu,A\Sigma A^T)$
  13. $\Big((x-\mu)^T\Sigma^{-1}(x-\mu)\Big)\sim\chi^2$
